Award.AwardTitle: Large-Scale and Predictable Organization of Nanocrystal Homo- and Heterojunctions through Polymer-Directed Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is the scalable fabrication of plasmonic nanojunctions, the nanometer-sized gaps created between high-curvature metal surfaces that produce intense electromagnetic ?hot spots.? In this project, metal nanocrystals will be self-organized to form precise nanojunctions by carrying out phase segregation within a nanocrystal-polymer composite. Nanocrystals will be assembled with respect to shape and orientation to create homojunction (similar) and heterojunction (dissimilar) nanocrystal pairs. Molecular simulations will be used to deduce the global phase diagram of the multicomponent nanocrystal-polymer mixtures and to predict the mechanisms and kinetics of large-scale nanocrystal assembly. Guided by simulations, nanocrystals will be chemically modified by polymer grafts with tailored chain lengths, grafting density, and charge. Detailed morphology studies of the resulting nanocomposite will provide insight into how the chemical nature of the nanocrystal surface can be used to tune the key intermolecular interactions that regulate orientation and arrangement of the plasmonic nanojunctions.

The results of this project will facilitate the successful fabrication of large-area, non-close-packed plasmonic nanocrystals arrays that are currently inaccessible by top-down fabrication methods. These nanomaterials will be designed for integration into optical device platforms for applications such as subwavelength focusing, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, and electromagnetic transparency. This work will also provide a fundamental understanding of the general mechanisms governing polymer-directed nanocrystal assembly. By establishing a close collaboration between experiment and theory, this work has the potential for the discovery of novel self-assembly pathways and mechanisms for achieving new and complex nanomaterials architectures. In addition, this research project will contribute to the education of pre-college, undergraduate, and graduate students in the field of nanoengineering. This includes the design of new laboratory modules and research-based coursework for undergraduates as well as outreach activities that will increase the overall diversity of the undergraduate engineering population at UCSD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the scalable fabrication of precise nanojunctions, which are the nanometer-sized gaps created by assembling nanocrystals into organized groups and arrangements. We exploited these nanojunctions for their ability to focus light and to produce intense electromagnetic “hot spots.” Multiscale modeling was implemented to predict how nanocrystals interact with polymers grafted to their surface and with each other. Guided by simulations, we carried out assembly experiments to validate these predictions and to generate functional nanocrystal-polymer composites for optical applications. A major finding of this project is that shaped nanocrystals are able to adopt specific orientations, and that these orientations are dictated by polymer graft lengths and graft composition. We demonstrated this using both modeling and experiment. We were successful in correlating theoretical parameters used in these simulations directly to experimental variables used in assembly experiments. This will allow computational models of nanoparticle assembly to serve as useful and practical tools for nanomanufacturing. Another major result is the development of analytical software that can be used to carry out fully automated image analysis. This software provided us with the capability to take snapshots of nanocrystal-polymer composites and analyze how their morphologies changed with time.

Our work on self-orientation has demonstrated that nanoparticle-polymer composites can be leveraged to design complex nanostructures with advanced functionality (such as light localization). Our work has demonstrated that self-assembly is a competitive and feasible technique for metamaterials nanomanufacturing. Our approach of assembling polymer-nanocrystal composites achieves nanoscale features that are difficult to fabricate in a scalable fashion by other competing methods, such as 3D printing. Many researchers have begun to use metal nanocrystals as building blocks for metamaterials and metasurfaces.

 We have also carried out a number of activities that will lead to a diverse and knowledgeable future workforce in nanotechnology. Our educational outreach activities include hosting underrepresented high school students as research interns during the summer. These students were recruited from the local San Diego and Tijuana areas, and are typically interested in pursuing a career in science or engineering. We have also developed new, experiential training for undergraduates at UCSD by integrating our research results into the curriculum of the NanoEngineering Department’s senior design course. This project has also provided numerous opportunities for students, post-docs, and the principal investigators to present their research findings both nationally and internationally. These experiences will properly equip our students and post-docs for careers in nanomanufacturing and to become leaders in evolving nanotechnology industries.
